Inspired by @mattlakajev

The 1 thing you should do if you don't have clients

(This will trigger you. I promise)

1) Spend 3 hours creating your micro offer
2) Message 100s of your ICP every single day
3) Ask them about their problems + what they need
4) Share your offer doc and ask for their feedback
5) Rewrite your offer doc based on what they say
6) Keep rewriting it again and again + add FAQs
7) Get on calls and offer to help them for free
8) Deliver them as much value as you can
9) Record the call and ask for kinda words
10) Use this as your first testimonial
11) Keep doing this over and over
12) Build up your conviction
13) Then start pitching
14) Get clients

Everything else is procrastination from
Doing the only things you should be doing

Thing 1 - Reaching out potential clients
Thing 2 - Getting on calls to help them

Everything else is just tactics
To help start more conversations.

→ Your profile
→ Your content
→ Your commenting

But they're not required to have them...

→ The reason you should not "build things"
→ Is because you have not spent enough time
→ Working with clients to know what they need.

And if you have a build-first, this will happen

You'll spend weeks on your offer
You'll talk to 5 people realising it's wrong
You'll spend weeks on your offer once again
You'll talk to 5 more people again realising it's wrong

This will happen over and over and over again

Until you start thinking

→ It must be my niche that sucks
→ It must be the algo that sucks
→ It must be me that sucks

It will crush you.

→ But it's none of these things
→ It's just that you're working
→ On the wrong stuff.

This is how you get clients

Sell like crazy > then build

→ Logic tells you to build first
→ Logic is lying to your face
→ Logic is why 99% fail

But "building" feels good
And conversations feel bad.

But that's the thing

→ When it feels bad
→ When it feels weird
→ When it starts to hurt

That's when you know, you're doing the right thing.

This is what all my clients did who are winning...

They threw shame out the fucking window
And decided that short-term discomfort
Was worth a life of fuck you money.

A life of freedom.

You decide...

PS - Want to get started for FREE?

These are 30 things I wish I knew when I started

1) Follow top copywriters
↳ And learn how to write

2) Followers don't equal $
↳ Don't let the gurus fool you

3) Cold outreach doesn't work
↳ Is some serious bull sh*t

4) DMs don’t get dopamine
↳ But they do get you the $

5) Learn how to use LI sales nav
↳ If you're serious about $$$

6) Lead magnet giveaway posts
↳ Are honestly a magic trick

7) Don't neglect your 1st degree 
↳ You can send tons of DM's

8) You'll start to feel comfortable
↳ After about 1 year on here

9) Creators who take LI seriously
↳ Are implementing the 3 C's 

10) Your content will suck unless
↳ You understand copywriting

11) If content gets low impressions
↳ 90% chance your hook sucks

12) When you think of post ideas
↳ Write it down → it's fleeting

13) 30 chats start a day should be
↳ Your No.1 metric if you want $

14) There's 100 things better than
↳ A calendar link in your featured

15) The best time to post is when
↳ You can be consistent long term

16) Using pinned comments means
↳ Can post more than once a day

17) The goal of your profile should be
↳ To take your ICP to the next step

18) If someone has the loudest voice
↳ It doesn't mean you should listen

19) You can spend 8 hours/day on here
↳ For no $ by doing the wrong things

20) If want to takes LinkedIn seriously
↳ Get a coach that's walked the walk

21) 5k accounts earn more in a month
↳ Than some 100k accounts in a year

22) You need to get over being "salesy"
↳ Otherwise you'll make no money here

23) Commenting gets you big engagement
↳ But not always big $ unless done right

24) Your content is not adequate follow up
↳ If you can help it's your duty to reach out 

25) If you're selling high ticket and don't DM
↳ Then I'd not even both posting content

26) You better get comfortable taking selfies
↳ Because they build trust the fastest

27) You can’t half ass LinkedIn to make it work
↳ Every creator I know spends 2-4 hrs a day

28) Coffee chats are an excuse for not doing
↳ The thing you're avoiding → which is selling 

29) Your profile optimsation doesn't mean sh*it
↳ If you don't have ICP's viewing your profile

30) You can post for 12 mths and book no meetings
↳ Or you can spend 1 day messaging and book five

Inspired by @mattlakajev

I just watched the Jasmin Alić and Chris Do interview

Here are 3 things I agree with

And 3 things I disagree with (Yep...😮)


𝗔𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝟭 - Impressions dropping doesn’t matter. 

This is true. What matters is leads generated per post. 

Similar to how Jasmin's Profile Viewers

→ You should track leads
→ Then look back at the month
→ See which generated the most

And make 3 more posts like them.

𝗗𝗶𝘀𝗮𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝟭 - You shouldn't sell in your posts

→ My coach coached Hormozi and Dan Martell. 
→ He helped 50 people hit 7 figures in a year. 
→ He sells in his posts and his emails. 

Jasmin is the best audience and community builder on LinkedIn. You are not.

Lose the shame. It's salesy or broke.

𝗔𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝟮 - AI comments are trash

→ They damage your personal brand
→ They make you look like and idiot
→ They show you don't respect the author

Don't do it.

𝗗𝗶𝘀𝗮𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝟮 - End your post the same way each time

The "don't make them think" ending is a good tactic, but not an always tactic.

Justin Welsh is the GOAT at $. 

Every one of his posts do 2 things

1) A link to sell his course
2) Pushes to his newsletter

Where he sells to you 24/7 in the inbox.

That's why he's made $8.1M

𝗔𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝟯 - The 3 line hack

This is brilliant (And I'm gonna steal it)

Rule 101 of copywriting

Your ad should not look like an ad, and you'll sell more.

→ Tell a story that resonates
→ People will see themself in it
→ They'll be compelled to take action

𝗗𝗶𝘀𝗮𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝟯 - Text-only posts are the best

No...

→ Some people like video
→ Some people like images
→ Some people like reading

You only get 1-2 posts a day. So pack them with value

E.g.

→ I'll write about how to write to get leads
→ I'll add 3 min tactical video with more value
→ I'll have a link at end to a 20 min free training.

I'll capture their email, and I'll sell in the inbox.


Overall it was a 10/10 video.

→ I also have 400+ testimonials (I know what I'm doing)

Inspired by @mattlakajev

I was judged for referencing the Bible last week

Here’s my response:

1. I’m not Christian, but I grew up in a Christian household. I respect Christians and anyone who chooses to practice their faith.

2. My wife is Indian, and her family follows Hinduism. I’ve spent countless hours learning and appreciating their traditions, and I deeply respect their beliefs.

3. One of my team members, Harris, is from Pakistan. He celebrates Eid, a significant Muslim holiday, and I encourage him to take that time off to be with his family because it’s important to him. I fully support that.

Here’s the thing: it doesn’t matter what religion someone follows—or if they follow one at all.

Everyone deserves the right to their own beliefs, and that deserves respect.

If your immediate reaction to someone referencing religion is judgment, hate, or discomfort, it says more about you than it does about them. 

We all have beliefs. Respect other people’s beliefs.

Learn to process different ideas, even ones you don’t agree with.

If you can’t do that, you’re not someone I want to associate with. 

This space is for people who can think critically, engage meaningfully, and respect others for their own experiences and perspectives.

Even if those beliefs, are different to your own…

Agree?

It was Pa's 90th birthday yesterday

At cake time my siblings and I got up to do a speech.

I talked about one of his best qualities

Listening.

You know when you go to a party and everyones chatting in a group

And you can tell, people are just waiting for their turn to speak?

Everyone does it, but not my Pa.

He never talks about himself
He only asks you questions.

How’s the dogs?
How’s Tanisha doing?
How’s that LinkedIn thing?

He’s been doing this for decades and

You feel seen by him
You feel heard by him
You trust him to your core.

When I mentioned this in my speech I saw all 60 people in the room nod.

They all trust my Pa.

My Pa is the greatest salesperson in the world.

Sales isn’t about 

Discount
Manipulation
Pressuring people

You win sales with

Brutal honesty
Childlike curiosity
And genuine empathy.

It’s about

You actually giving a shit
You doing the right thing
Even if it means losing the sale.

You're helping > selling

So if you’re a small business owner who wants to learn how to sell on LinkedIn without feeling salesy – just like my Pa does

Where you'll learn how to
Sell without feeling salesly.

What Do Property Managers Do?
They're the middleman between landlords & tenants. 

- Collect Rent & handle evictions
- Handle Maintenance
- Lease Units (market & screen tenants)
- Stay Compliant with landlord-tenant laws

It's operationally complex but that makes it sticky

CoFounders Nik
@CoFoundersNik
·
10m
The 3 Ways They Make Money
Property management has three main revenue streams:
1. Rent Collection: % of rent or flat monthly fee/unit
2. Maintenance: Either in-house or markup on contractors
3. Leasing: Fees for finding & screening tenants

The best operators optimize all three

CoFounders Nik
@CoFoundersNik
·
10m
How Much Can You Make?
Revenue/Door: $150-$300/month depending on efficiency

Profit Margins: 10-18% (top PMs hit 20%+)

Regional Differences: Coastal markets = higher revenue per door

Sweet Spot: 700+ doors = leadership team + owner can step back

CoFounders Nik
@CoFoundersNik
·
10m
Why Do PE Firms Love These?
- Highly recurring revenue (sticky contracts)
- No AR issues (Fees come right from rent payments)
- Lots of efficiencies at scale
- Low CapEx needs (All CapEx is on the landlord)

That’s why big firms pay 1.5-2x revenue for PM businesses

How to Start or Buy a PM Business
From scratch:
- Get a RE broker’s license (required in most states)
- Market on Google Business Profile, PPC, SEO
- Build referral partnerships w/ landlords & realtors
- Use BiggerPockets & REI meetups

Buy one: Look for 100-300 door firms

Inspired by @mattlakajev

12 life lessons my wife taught me that made me the man I am today

1 - You don’t need a personal brand to make money. She doesn’t post content. She's 10x more successful than me. You make $ through relationships.

2 - Hard work is the only way to get better. Eating sh*t on the daily. That’s how you win.

3 - Fashion matters. People judge you based on how you look. She thought Hormozi looked homeless. Dress well. Respect yourself. 

4 - Don’t trust easily. Everyone is out there for themselves. Make them earn it.

5  - Anxiety is only temporary. You can always take on more. Keep going.

6 - We aren’t made of glass. For 6mths she worked 8pm-5am. She didn’t complain. She’s a weapon.

7 - There’s no advantage in telling everyone everything. There’s always an advantage to pretending you know less than you do. Hold your cards close to your chest

8 - Drop your sh*tty friends. They don’t care about you. You know who they are. They’re only bringing you down. 

9 - Rest is crucial. You need to slow down, to speed up. 

10 - You show love through what you do, not what you say.

11 - Life sucks without having fun. Stop being so serious. Be silly. You’ll feel better.

12 - When you love someone, love them all the way, or don’t love them at all.

In a world that's always judged me, Tanisha never wavered cheering me on.

Through the good times and the bad. She's my forever person. And I'm lucky to have her.

Inspired by @mattlakajev

How I closed $660,600 on WhatsApp in 6 mths

(28% wearing green socks with Zoom slides)

After earning $0 my first 6 months...

I started LinkedIn Dec 22

→ I did the coffee chats thing
→ I did the 2hrs commenting thing
→ I did the posting consistently thing

But I earned $0

→ Since then I built a DM process
→ That's taken me to 7 figures a year
→ Without having any sales meetings

(That you can steal and use for free)

Here's the 3 step breakdown


1) My Outbound (40% of my leads)

I start 30 new chats a day

With anyone who

→ Views my profile
→ Sends me a connection
→ Opts in for me lead magnet

I send hyper personalised and relevant messages

"𝘏𝘦𝘺 𝘕𝘈𝘔𝘌 - 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘯𝘬𝘴 𝘧𝘰𝘳 {𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘦𝘳𝘵 𝘸𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘥𝘪𝘥}.
{𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘦𝘳𝘵 𝘰𝘣𝘴𝘦𝘳𝘷𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘢𝘣𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘪𝘳 𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘧𝘪𝘭𝘦}. {𝘛𝘪𝘦
𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘰𝘣𝘴𝘦𝘳𝘷𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘵𝘰 𝘴𝘰𝘮𝘦𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘢𝘣𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘺𝘰𝘶}.
𝘞𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘱𝘪𝘳𝘦𝘥 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘵𝘰 𝘱𝘰𝘴𝘵 𝘰𝘯 𝘓𝘪𝘯𝘬𝘦𝘥𝘐𝘯?

(I get an 80% acceptance rate here)

→ I then qualify people HARD by asking
→ 3-4 "peeling back the onion" questions
→ Which can take from 1 day - 3 months

For LinkedIn it's LT relationships
→ Not short term transactions

Once I've asked the questions
→ I propose a WhatsApp chat

(85% of people accept)


2) My Inbound (60% of my leads)

I use a single 3 step VSL funnel on my profile

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟭 - A landing page with headline + sub headline with 11 minute VSL and 1 CTA

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟮 - When you click the "Interested? Chat With Matt" it goes to form to enter details

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟯 -  Then finally it goes to the Calendar link which only allows to book 3 days out


3) My WhatsApp DM Sales Process

I run a 2 step sales process

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟭 - I run a 30 min Triage WhatsApp chat

→ The agenda being to ask questions
→ To see if they might be a good fit
→ If they are we book another chat

(Making sure it's in 1-3 days time)

Which

Inspired by @mattlakajev

SBA loans have low default rates, right?

Bob sat in his cramped home office, surrounded by stacks of maintenance contracts and crew schedules. 

Three years ago, he'd been a rising executive at a Fortune 500 company, pulling in $205,000 a year plus bonuses. 

Now he was the proud owner of "Premium Landscape Solutions"—purchased with a big ass SBA loan that had seemed like such an obvious move.

SBA loans have low default rates, right?

Youtube made buying a business so OBVIOUS and the business broker had made it sound perfect....an established landscaping company with recurring maintenance contracts, reliable crews, and a strong reputation in an affluent suburb. 

"A steady business with great cash flow," he'd read, "and room to expand into high-end landscape design!" 

The numbers supported his pitch: Healthy margins, and a seemingly reasonable purchase price. 

With the SBA covering 90%, James only needed to put down $130,000—a fraction of his savings after 10 years in corporate America.

Bob already had ideas of other companies he could buy!

He remembered his wife's concerned expression when he'd explained his plan to "escape the corporate rat race." 

She'd supported him, of course, but her eyes had betrayed her worry. 

Their youngest had just elementary school and she was pregnant with their second. 

Her salary had supported everyone while Bob "pursued his dream" of being an entrepreneur....

...because SBA loans have low default rates, right?

The spreadsheets he'd created showed they still could—the business would generate enough income to maintain their lifestyle and then some. 

He'd even used his Six Sigma training to map out process improvements that would boost efficiency by at least 30%.

Then one day - he actually had to run and own the business. 

The people around the transaction evaporated, the business influencer made their $899 on the course, and it was time to start interacting with reality.

Reliable crews turned out to mean "reliable until something better came along." 

Weather created havoc with scheduling—every rainy day meant lost revenue he could never recover. 

Equipment broke down constantly; the previous owner hadn't mentioned that half the mowers were on their last legs, and Bob had never repaired anything in his life.

Each season brought its own challenges: spring's overwhelming demand, summer's brutal heat and crew shortages, fall's race against time to complete projects before winter, and winter's nerve-wracking lull.

His corporate experience, which he'd thought would give him an edge, often proved a hindrance. 

Crews didn't care about his "strategic vision" or process optimization initiatives. 

They just wanted their paychecks on time and another few bucks an hour.

His attempts to implement professional management systems were met with resistance or blank stares. 

Bob had so many ideas to make thing better. 

He just didn't have the team, cash, or energy to make them happen. 

The business didn't need a former executive; it needed someone who could handle endless equipment repairs, manage weather-dependent scheduling, and deal with increasingly demanding clients who expected country club results on a suburban budget.

The business wasn't failing—he made his $7,200 monthly loan payment without fail. 

Because SBA loans have low default rates, right?

But his personal income had dropped to less than a third of his former salary, and he was working 2X as much.

The crews got paid, the suppliers got paid, the bank got paid, and James got whatever was left over. 

Thoreau's words haunted him during his long drives between job sites: 

"The cost of a thing is the amount of what I will call life which is required to be exchanged for it." 

Almost a decade of loan payments stretched ahead of him—seven more years of missed family dinners, canceled vacations, and constant stress about weather forecasts and equipment breakdowns.

He knew he probably wasn't going to miss a payment, because SBA loans have low default rates, right? He remembers the broker telling him that.

The worst part wasn't the money or even the hours—it was the creeping realization that he'd traded his life's prime years for a cage of his own design. 

He was stuck in an endless cycle of crew management and customer complaints, too financially committed to walk away, too proud to admit he'd made a mistake, and too exhausted to figure out an exit strategy. 

Bob's story would never appear in the glowing SBA default statistics that lured him in, yet he paid a devastating price measured not in dollars but in missed bedtime stories, mounting health problems, and the quiet death of his professional dreams. 

While the brokers, business influencers, and loan officers had made their money and moved on to their next deal, Bob remained trapped in a cage of his own making....too financially committed to escape and too exhausted to find a way out. 

In pursuing the promise of entrepreneurial freedom, he had only succeeded in trading his corporate shackles for a heavier set—ones that bound not just his career, but his health, his family life, and his future to a business that owned him far more than he would ever own it.

But it's all ok, because SBA loans have low default rates, right?

Be careful out there amigos.

You might have noticed I’ve been a bit hard to find on LinkedIn recently.

But don’t worry—I'm back!

Here’s what happened:

Someone tried to get into my account.

They didn’t get far, thanks to LinkedIn’s security. 

But it triggered a safeguard that temporarily locked me out.

Losing access to my account for 10 hours sucked. 

But here’s the silver lining:

• My account wasn’t compromised.
• My reputation stayed intact.
• And LinkedIn had my back.

I’ve since tightened up my password management, and this is your friendly reminder to do the same.

Now, let me just say—LinkedIn gets a lot of heat for its rules and restrictions. 

I get it. 

But when push comes to shove, they’re here to protect a billion people. 

That’s not easy, and today, it worked.

I also want to thank every single person who reached out, messaged, or even rallied with hashtags like #BringMattBack.

You reminded me why I love this platform so much.

• LinkedIn has changed my life.
• It’s helped me help others.
• It’s helped me build.

And today, it showed me again why it’s worth being here.

So, hats off to LinkedIn—and a huge thank you to all of you.

Now, let’s get back to winning on this epic platform.

Let's go!

I’ve been studying personal branding for 6 years.

Want to know the biggest mistake executives make?

They try to be everything to everyone.

The math is simple:
• Generic content = Generic results
• Generic results = Missed opportunities
• Missed opportunities = Lost revenue

Here's what actually works:

Pick ONE problem you solve better than anyone.
Tell ONE story that shows why.
Speak to ONE specific audience.

Example:
Instead of "I help businesses grow"

Try "I help SaaS founders reduce their churn by 15%”

The riches are in the niches.

Your expertise isn't general.
Why is your content?

After 18 months I hit 40,000 followers

These are 30 things I wish I knew when I started

1) Follow top copywriters
↳ And learn how to write

2) Followers don't equal $
↳ Don't let the gurus fool you

3) Cold outreach doesn't work
↳ Is some serious bull sh*t

4) DMs don’t get dopamine
↳ But they do get you the $

5) Learn how to use LI sales nav
↳ If you're serious about $$$

6) Lead magnet giveaway posts
↳ Are honestly a magic trick

7) Don't neglect your 1st degree 
↳ You can send tons of DM's

8) You'll start to feel comfortable
↳ After about 1 year on here

9) Creators who take LI seriously
↳ Are implementing the 3 C's 

10) Your content will suck unless
↳ You understand copywriting

11) If content gets low impressions
↳ 90% chance your hook sucks

12) When you think of post ideas
↳ Write it down → it's fleeting

13) 30 chats start a day should be
↳ Your No.1 metric if you want $

14) There's 100 things better than
↳ A calendar link in your featured

15) The best time to post is when
↳ You can be consistent long term

16) Using pinned comments means
↳ Can post more than once a day

17) The goal of your profile should be
↳ To take your ICP to the next step

18) If someone has the loudest voice
↳ It doesn't mean you should listen

19) You can spend 8 hours/day on here
↳ For no $ by doing the wrong things

20) If want to takes LinkedIn seriously
↳ Get a coach that's walked the walk

21) 5k accounts earn more in a month
↳ Than some 100k accounts in a year

22) You need to get over being "salesy"
↳ Otherwise you'll make no money here

23) Commenting gets you big engagement
↳ But not always big $ unless done right

24) Your content is not adequate follow up
↳ If you can help it's your duty to reach out 

25) If you're selling high ticket and don't DM
↳ Then I'd not even both posting content

26) You better get comfortable taking selfies
↳ Because they build trust the fastest

27) You can’t half ass LinkedIn to make it work
↳ Every creator I know spends 2-4 hrs a day

28) Coffee chats are an excuse for not doing
↳ The thing you're avoiding → which is selling 

29) Your profile optimsation doesn't mean sh*it
↳ If you don't have ICP's viewing your profile

30) You can post for 12 mths and book no meetings
↳ Or you can spend 1 day messaging and book five

This was taken at the Sangeet night of our wedding last year. It was only day 2 of the 3 day celebration. So grateful for the experience. Indian weddings rock!

PS - What would you add as 31?

I sold myself onto a 2.62M subscriber podcast

With 1 cold DM and 1 post. Here’s how:

2 weeks ago I watched the Chris Do and Jasmin Alić YouTube video.

→ As I watched I was
→ Agreeing with some things
→ But disagreeing with more. 

“How can this be the best YT video on LinkedIn? It doesn’t even scratch sales. And it won’t help people make money...”

I was gutted.

→ But what could I do?
→ These guys are huge
→ I’m tiny compared to them.

I thought for hours, until finally, I worked it out.

→ I was going to sell myself on 
→ Using 2 tactics that Jasmin 
→ Said you should never do

1 - "The key to selling in your content is actually not selling."
2 - Cold DMs are not as effective

I got to work

→ I researched Chris Do
→ Going deep into his content
→ To see what he cared about.

(A tactic I teach 629 students)

→ His biggest priority right now
→ Is selling his program that helps
→ Creatives build their businesses 

And sell… Perfect 😊

First, I Cold DMd him this

“𝘏𝘦𝘺 𝘊𝘩𝘳𝘪𝘴, 𝘫𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘤𝘩𝘦𝘤𝘬𝘦𝘥 𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘴𝘦𝘯𝘥 𝘠𝘛 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩 𝘑𝘢𝘴𝘮𝘪𝘯. 𝘌𝘱𝘪𝘤. 𝘈𝘭𝘴𝘰 𝘯𝘰𝘵𝘪𝘤𝘦𝘥 𝘺𝘰𝘶’𝘷𝘦 𝘣𝘦𝘦𝘯 𝘱𝘰𝘴𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘰𝘯𝘴 𝘮𝘰𝘳𝘦 𝘢𝘣𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘴𝘢𝘭𝘦𝘴. 𝘞𝘰𝘶𝘭𝘥 𝘭𝘰𝘷𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘨𝘦𝘵 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘣𝘢𝘤𝘬 𝘶𝘱 𝘙𝘪𝘤𝘩𝘢𝘳𝘥 𝘔𝘰𝘰𝘳𝘦 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩 𝘴𝘰𝘮𝘦 𝘮𝘰𝘳𝘦 𝘠𝘛 𝘴𝘢𝘭𝘦𝘴 𝘤𝘰𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘯𝘵 𝘰𝘯 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘱𝘰𝘥𝘤𝘢𝘴𝘵. 𝘓𝘦𝘵 𝘮𝘦 𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸 𝘪𝘧 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘮𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵 𝘣𝘦 𝘰𝘱𝘦𝘯 𝘵𝘰 𝘪𝘵? 𝘊𝘩𝘦𝘦𝘳𝘴, 𝘔𝘢𝘵𝘵”

Next, I spent 1 hr on the post

In it, I made sure

1 - To not disrespect Jasmin (You should never bash the competition)

2 - To clearly articulate my points (Clear communication is key in sales)

3 - To get support from other saying others want me on (200 people commented “Chris”)

4 - To prove that I would help his audience (I added social proof in the post)

5 - To make the next step easy for Chris (I added my email in the post)

On Saturday afternoon, I posted it.

And then…. Nothing
So I waited….Still nothing
Checked before bed….Still nothing 

Maybe I wasn’t as good as I thought I was 🤷‍♂️ 

→ Sunday morning
→ I woke up and went
→ Straight into LinkedIn

From Chris — “𝘔𝘢𝘵𝘵, 𝘐’𝘮 𝘨𝘢𝘮𝘦”

→ I f*cking did it. 
→ But you know what?
→ I knew I was going to 😉 

All this bs about

→ “Don’t being salesy”
→ Is a narrative being pushed by
→ People that don’t know how to sell

The right way…

And on February 7th, I’ll teach you how…

PS - What should I talk about on the podcast?

I can't stop thinking about this art exhibit in Japan.

A chained robot dog will try to attack you:

It's designed to highlight our need for AI safety.

Some see a machine that needs restraining.
Others feel empathy for a chained creation.

But here's what's really happening:

• It's programmed to pursue human targets
• The chain is the only thing holding it back
• It follows objectives without emotion or empathy
• Those objectives can be changed at will

The real-world parallels are chilling:

→ US Marines testing armed robot dogs
→ Military AI development accelerating
→ Autonomous weapons becoming reality

It reminds me of Black Mirror's “Metalhead”.

Survival against relentless robotic “killer dogs” inspired by Boston Dynamics.

As Palantir's CEO Alex Karp noted:
“We must not shy away from building sharp tools for fear they may be turned against us.”

The exhibit forces us to confront uncomfortable questions:

1) What happens when the chain comes off?
2) Who controls these technologies?
3) Where do we draw the line?

My takeaway:

The best and worst outcomes in technology aren't about the machines.

They're about the humans who control them.

Follow me Alex Banks for daily AI highlights and insights.

Want to start leveraging AI?
